page.title: 20The Caradon Railway.
page.content: { Copper}made Cornwall a leader in world mining, and made{Caradon Hill rich and famous. The{Liskeard and Caradon Railway {Act}was granted on{26th June,1843. Money was collected and the line was laid at a cost of Â£27,000. Waggons of ore descended by gravity and returned pulled by horses, then at a later date, by locomotives. The line from Caradon passed through Polwrath, St. Cleer and Tremabe to Moorswater. There were no tunnels, only bridges and cuttings. The track may still be followed for part of the way. In a year about{7,000 tons of copper and{8,000 tons of granite}descended, and{1,600 tons of coal, iron and wood ascended the line. In 1859 there were 27 employees-14 brakesmen,5 labourers, 2 platelayers,a secretary, treasurer, foreman and a policeman.
